---
title: "Statistical Concepts"
author: "Rithika Rao Dodda"
number-sections: false
---

# Assignment


::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_4acb69e1bbf962b9cc4e9a7d6fb8e839'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Load the file
random_variable <- readRDS("Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")
# Creating a Data Frame
df=data.frame(random_variable)
```
:::


1. For each variable, Compute the following

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_3d63f0df064ebe45559cf7a3d01e516c'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 1.Mean 
mean(df$age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 33.471
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(df$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 3510.731
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_d2527256556d4cb700307b145b602473'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 2. Variance
var(df$age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 340.6078
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
var(df$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 8625646
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_6eb462415af858afca249d949dfb8d80'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 3. Standard deviation
sd(df$age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 18.45556
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
sd(df$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 2936.945
```
:::
:::


2. The estimated Standard deviations are on wide range of scales. Because of this, comparing them makes no sense.

3. Calculate Covariance and Correlation


::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_3952d683f5e37e18b755f13ae8adedd2'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Covariance
cov(df)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#>               age     income
#> age      340.6078   29700.15
#> income 29700.1468 8625645.84
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_deb79f3295c37072384f8abbfcdfedc4'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Correlation
cor(df)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#>              age    income
#> age    1.0000000 0.5479432
#> income 0.5479432 1.0000000
```
:::
:::


4.  Correlation is easy to interpret as it is a standardized measure. When age is increasing the income is also increasing as the correlation is a positive value.

5. Compute the Conditional Expected value

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_e9fc8718980f2539735f68e0ae76e3a4'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 1 Creating a subset for finding the mean of income for age below 18
age_18 <- subset(df, age<=18, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_18$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 389.6074
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_c627e95655374d64572b66aceb901ed2'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 2 Creating a subset for finding the mean of income for age above 65
age_65 <- subset(df, age>=65, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_65$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 1777.237
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_9acee1cfab6dd24a796b010e365d2239'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 3 Creating subset to find the mean income between age 18 and 65
age_18_65 <- subset(df, age>=18 & age<65, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_18_65$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 4685.734
```
:::
:::
